claim: People born in the 1900s are over 100 years old in 2025

supporting.text: The year 1900 is 125 years before 2025, so anyone born in 1900 would be 125 years old in 2025.

attacks.text: The year 1900 is 125 years before 2025, so anyone born in 1900 would be 125 years old in 2025.
The claim refers to 'the 1900s' (1900-1999), not just the year 1900. Most people born in the 1900s would not be over 100 in 2025.
The original argument (A1) correctly addresses the edge case of those born in 1900, which technically falls under 'the 1900s' and supports the claim for that specific year.
The claim is misleading because it implies all or most people born in the 1900s are over 100 in 2025, when only those born in or before 1925 would meet that criterion.
The claim does not explicitly state 'all' or 'most,' so it remains technically true for some subset of people born in the 1900s (e.g., those born in 1900-1925).

attacks.text: A person born in 1901 would be 124 years old in 2025, which is still over 100 years old.
The claim generalizes all people born in the 1900s, but only those born in 1900 or 1901 would be over 100 in 2025.
The claim is technically correct for some individuals (e.g., born in 1900-1901), but misleading as a general statement.
Most people born in the 1900s (e.g., 1980-1999) would not be over 100 in 2025.

supporting.text: The 1900s span from 1900 to 1999, and the earliest birth year in this range (1900) ensures all such individuals are at least 125 years old in 2025.

attacks.text: The 1900s span from 1900 to 1999, and the earliest birth year in this range (1900) ensures all such individuals are at least 125 years old in 2025.
The term '1900s' is often colloquially interpreted as the decade of 1900–1909, not the entire century, which would include younger individuals.
Historical and linguistic consensus defines '1900s' as the entire century (1900–1999), not just the decade, making A3's interpretation more accurate.

The claim specifies 'people born in the 1900s,' implying all individuals in that range, not just the oldest, so B2's counter is valid.

supporting.text: Mathematically, subtracting 1900 from 2025 yields 125, confirming that the minimum age for someone born in the 1900s in 2025 is 125.

attacks.text: Mathematically, subtracting 1900 from 2025 yields 125, confirming that the minimum age for someone born in the 1900s in 2025 is 125.

supporting.text: Even the youngest possible person born in the 1900s (December 31, 1999) would be 25 years old in 2025, but the claim specifies 'over 100,' which is true for all earlier birth years.

attacks.text: Even the youngest possible person born in the 1900s (December 31, 1999) would be 25 years old in 2025, but the claim specifies 'over 100,' which is true for all earlier birth years.
The claim is ambiguous—it could be interpreted as 'all people born in the 1900s are over 100 in 2025,' which is false for those born after 1924.
The original argument correctly interprets the claim as a general statement about the 1900s, not an absolute assertion about every individual.
The claim is misleading because it implies a universal condition, but the majority of people born in the 1900s (post-1924) are not over 100 in 2025.

supporting.text: Demographic data shows that the oldest living people in 2025 were born in the early 1900s, all exceeding 100 years of age.

attacks.text: Demographic data shows that the oldest living people in 2025 were born in the early 1900s, all exceeding 100 years of age.
Not all people born in the early 1900s survived until 2025; many died before reaching 100 years of age.
